Information Included: Historical maps from approximately 1850 onwards (1:1250; 1:2500; 1:10000); potential sources of contamination
Note: Maps need to be reviewed by an enviromental consultant to identify potential sources of contamination

Information Included: Historical land uses from approximately 1850 onwards (map scale variable); potential sources of contamination
Note: Maps need to be reviewed by an enviromental consultant to identify potential sources of contamination

Information Included: Potential sources of contamination as interpreted from historical mapping
Note: Check limitations prior to using the dataset

Information Included: Potential sources of contamination as interpreted from historical mapping
Note: Check limitations prior to using the dataset

Information Included: Artificial ground (including infilled land); superficial geology; bedrock geology; geological faults; coal seams; boreholes; wells etc.
Artificial ground (including infilled land); superficial geology; bedrock geology; geological faults; coal seams; boreholes; wells; geological logs etc.
Note: Most geological logs are scanned in, limited number of logs is available in AGS

Information Included: More detailed geology: Artificial ground (including infilled land); superficial geology; bedrock geology; geological faults; coal seams; cross-sections; detailed descriptions
Arsenic; benzo(a)pyrene; cadmium; chromium; copper; lead; mercury; nickel

Dataset: Contaminated Land Register Entries and Notices
Information Included: Land designated as "contaminated land" according to Part 2A of the Environmental Protection Act 1990
Source: Envirocheck; Groundsure; Local council websites; data.gov.uk
Note: Some councils have information available on websites including some detail about risk assessment, some on data.gov.uk as WMS layers, some on paid request (Kirklees Council)

Information Included: These data provide details of all permit details as required under the Environmental Permit Regulation. Information is held for all permit holders and covers all substances that are controlled.

Pollution controls/permits relating to air pollution controls (APC); integrated pollution control (IPC); integrated pollution prevention controls (IPPC); petrol filling stations (PFS); control of major accident hazards (COMAH); radioactive licences
Data Owner: Environment Agency; Local councils (Environmental Health Department)
Note: Data publically available only from some of the councils

Dataset: Nearest Surface Water Feature, River network lines
Information Included: Distance to the nearest surface water feature
Rivers; drainage; ponds etc.
OS Open Rivers maps over 144000 km of watercourses. Freshwater rivers; tidal estuaries and canals.
Statutory Main Rivers Map is a spatial (polyline) dataset that defines statutory watercourses in England designated as Main Rivers by Environment Agency.

Dataset: CEH digital river network of Great Britain
Information Included: This is a view service of the CEH 1:50k rivers dataset. This is a river centreline network based originally on OS 1:50000 mapping. Rivers; canals; surface pipes (man-made channels such as aqueducts and leats) and miscellaneous channels (including estuary and lake centre-lines and some underground channels).
The dataset only includes substantiated incidents and their environmental impact.
Note: Data previously available on data.gov.uk. The website states: "PLEASE NOTE: We have removed this dataset as ownership of the data within it no longer sits with a single organisation. The Environment Agency is currently working on a revised version of this dataset that covers incidents falling within the remit of the Environment Agency."

Information Included: The Water Quality Archive provides data on water quality measurements. Samples are taken at sampling points around England and can be from coastal or estuarine waters; rivers; lakes; ponds; canals or groundwaters.
Updated: Within two working days of a new sample being added

Information Included: River and Groundwater Catchments -  information about the water environment. It supports and builds upon the data in the river basin management plans.
Note: API information available, some data available only up to  2016

Information Included: Licenced groundwater and surface water abstractions (> 20 m3/day)
Non-licenced groundwater and surface water abstractions (< 20 m3/day)
Note: Private Water Supplies Regulations 2009, additional information to be potentially added during case study stage

Information Included: Unproductive; low; medium and high groundwater vulnerability. The importance of the groundwater resource is reflected in the aquifer designation status derived from the BGS's aquifer designation maps. Additional information includes soluble rock risk (areas where solution features that enable rapid movement of a pollutant may be present) and local information (areas where additional information that contributes to the understanding of groundwater vulnerability is held locally by the EA).
Source: Envirocheck; Groundsure; MAGIC maps; BGS website (by request)
Licence: Free for non-commercial reseearch and academic use; https://www.bgs.ac.uk/products/hydrogeology/GroundwaterVulnerability.html

Information Included: Bedrock and superficial aquifer designations (Principal; Secondary A; Seconday B; Secondary (undiffirentiated); Unproductive)
Source: Envirocheck; Groundsure; MAGIC maps; BGS website (by request)
Note: More information on licensing is needed

Information Included: Protection zones for abstraction for drinking water; possibility to approximately locate the abstraction itself
Historical/registered landfill sites
Local Authority Recorded Landfill Sites
Note: Can potentially include landfill sites recorded by local authorities (http://apps.environment-agency.gov.uk/wiyby/37829.aspx)

Information Included: Waste treatment; transfer and disposal sites; licensed waste management sites

Coal mining reporting areas; mine entries; abandoned mines; development high risk areas; surface coal resource areas; mine entry potential zone of influence; fissures and breaklines; surface mining (past and current); past shallow coal mine workings; probable shallow coal mine workings; coal outcrops; NE mining & groundwater constraints
Note: Coal mining report can be requested from Coal Authority in case there is high risk to the development; WMS data provided as a raster; Also provides information on geotechnical hazards

Information Included: Coal mining affected areas
Note: Also provides information on geotechnical hazards

Information Included: Coal mining report: Past underground coal mining; Present underground coal mining; Future underground coal mining; Mine entries;  Coal mining geology; Past opencast coal mining; Present opencast coal mining; Future opencast coal mining; Coal mining subsidence; Mine gas; Hazards related to coal mining; Withdrawal of support; Working facilities order; Payments to owners of former copyhold land
Source: The Coal Authority; Envirocheck website request
Note: Requested when coal mining risk identified; Also provides information on geotechnical hazards

Information Included: Recorded mineral sites; non-coal mining areas; brine compensation area
Data Owner: British Geological Survey; Cheshire Brine Subsidence Compensation Board

Information Included: Radon affected areas and required radon protection measures - data is averaged over 1 km2 (indicative dataset)
Data Owner: British Geological Survey; Public Health England

Information Included: Estimated probability that an address is above the Action Level for radon; Suitable for any home or small workplace under 25 metres in length
Note: Requested when Radon Potential - Indicative shows the property is in an area with increased radon risk; Not suitable for buildings over 25 meters in length and for site redevelopment

Information Included: Radon affected areas and required radon protection measures - accurate to 50 m (definitive dataset)
Data Owner: British Geological Survey; Public Health England

Information Included: This is an advisory report on the requirement for radon protective measures in new buildings; conversions and extensions to existing buildings. The report also indicates whether a site is located within a radon affected area. This report is based on the joint BGS - Public Health England (PHE) radon potential data and complies with "BR211 Radon: Guidance on protective measures for new buildings (2015 edition)"
Data Owner: British Geological Survey; Public Health England
Note: Recommended for buildings over 25 meters in length, groups of buildings and for site redevelopment

Information Included: Areas of Adopted Green Belt; Areas of Unadopted Green Belt
Licence: Public Sector End User Licence - INSPIRE
Note: Each council reports the data differently

Information Included: Areas of Outstanding Natural Beauty; Environmentally Sensitive Areas; Local Nature Reserves; Conservations Zones; National Parks; Ramsar Sites; Sites of Special Scientific Interest; Special Protection Areas and other
In these areas incentives were offered to farmers to undertake significant changes in agricultural practices to reduce nitrate leaching; thereby helping stabalise or reduce nitrate levels.
Nitrate Vulnerable Zones (NVZs) are areas designated as being at risk from agricultural nitrate pollution. They include about 55% of land in England.

Site location; borehole construction details; geology; groundwater strikes; groundwater and gas monitoring; concentrations of chemicals in soil; leachate; groundwater and surface water; pump/slug testing; walkover information; topography etc.
Format: AGS; PDF; Excel; CSV; GIS; CAD files; Photos
Note: AGS data contain borehole construction details, geology, groundwater strikes, groundwater and gas monitoring, concentrations of chemicals in soil, leachate, groundwater and surface water, pump testing

Information Included: Contamporary trade directories; railways and stations; electricity substations; works; petrol and fuel stations; vehicle repair; testing and servicing etc.
Note: Data owner for Groundsure data not identified

Information Included: Railways and stations; electricity substations; works; petrol and fuel stations; vehicle repair; testing and servicing etc.
Railways and stations; works; petrol and fuel stations etc.
High level assessment of regional WWII bombing densities - potential for unexploded bomb (UXB) to be present as a result of WWII bombing. Low/moderate/high risk area
Note: Preliminary risk assessment for potential unexploded ordnance (UXO), indicates whether detailed resarch by UXO specialist is required.

Information Included: Probability of UXO encounter; High Explosive Bomb Density; Threat Sources (e.g. airfields; ordnance manufacture/storage; WWII defensive bombing sites)
Note: Preliminary Unexploded Ordnance (UXO) Threat Assessment - as per requirements of CIRIA C681 Unexploded Ordnance (UXO) – 'A guide for the Construction Industry’ Risk Management Framework

Information Included: Soil Guideline Values & Category 4Screening Levels for assessing risk to human health receptors based on proposed site end-use

Atkins has developed ATRISKsoil Soil Screening Values (SSVs) and ATRISKsoil Water Screening Values (WSVs) applicable to the UK for use in assessing chronic human health exposure to commonly encountered contaminants.
Note: Atkins paid for service

Information Included: Screening values for controlled waters assessment: Environmental Quality Standards for surface waters and coastal waters; Drinking Water Standards (England and Wales); Resource Protection Values (Scotland); Site-specific PNEC (predicted no effect concentration)
Data Owner: UK Government; Scottish Environment Protection Agency

Information Included: Site-specific assessment criteria for metals (copper; lead; nickel; manganese; zinc) based on their bioavailability
Data Owner: Water Framework Directive – United Kingdom Technical Advisory Group
Note: Data from surface water receptor (pH; dissolved organic carbon and calcium) required as inputs

Information Included: Site-specific assessment criteria based on modelling outputs of Tier 3 risk assessment
Can be used when UK guidance doesn't provide a screening value for particular determinand. Potentially needs to be discussed with the regulator (Environment Agency; Natural resources Wales or SEPA).
Note: Only one example is included here

Information Included: Information on the processes; materials and waste associated with individual industries with regard to land contamination
For human health (e.g. CLEA model) and controlled waters assessment (e.g. ConSim model).
Format: Other data formats (e.g. ConSim model outputs); Excel; PDF

Information Included: Data interpretation and identification of relevant pollutant linkages and contaminants of concern
Note: Typically prepared as a table or a figure

Information Included: Can include for example positions of tanks on site; description of ways how people used to dispose of chemicals on site etc.
Desk study (Tier 1) and ground investigation interpretative (Tier 2) can be submitted as part of the pre-plannign application process

Desk study (Tier 1) and ground investigation interpretative (Tier 2) and other reports (e.g. coal mining report) are submitted as part of planning process; i.e. planning application and/or as part of diacharge of planning conditions. These reports can include all datasets listed above or only parts of those datasets.
Note: The information available on the planning portal changes as projects progress through various stages of planning. Desk study reports and ground investigation interpretative reports can be available for limited amount of time. Each local council has a different planning portal layout.
